transcript:
Therapist: Let's dive deeper into the CBT model and how it applies to your experiences. As we discussed, a key aspect of CBT is recognizing how our thoughts influence our emotions and behaviors. For example, when you received feedback from your supervisor, your thought was, "I'm not good enough, and I'll never be able to meet their expectations." This thought then led to feelings of hopelessness and inadequacy.

Patient: Right, I can see how that thought contributed to my negative emotions.

Therapist: Exactly. In CBT, we call these types of negative thoughts "cognitive distortions." Cognitive distortions are inaccurate or irrational thought patterns that can contribute to negative emotions and behaviors. Some common cognitive distortions include all-or-nothing thinking, overgeneralization, and jumping to conclusions.

Alejandro, I'm curious if you can identify any cognitive distortions in the thought you shared earlier about not being good enough and never meeting expectations.

Patient: Well, I suppose it could be considered all-or-nothing thinking. I'm assuming that because I didn't meet expectations in this one instance, I'll never be able to do so.

Therapist: That's a great insight, Alejandro. All-or-nothing thinking, also known as black-and-white thinking, is a common cognitive distortion where we view situations in extreme, absolute terms without considering the nuances or middle ground. In your case, you're assuming that one instance of not meeting expectations means you'll never be able to do so, without considering the possibility that you can learn and improve from this experience.

Another cognitive distortion that might be at play here is overgeneralization. Overgeneralization occurs when we take one negative experience and assume that it will always happen in similar situations. For example, if you have one negative interaction with a coworker, you might assume that all future interactions with coworkers will be negative.

Can you think of any other situations where you might have engaged in all-or-nothing thinking or overgeneralization?

Patient: Now that I think about it, I can see how I often engage in all-or-nothing thinking when it comes to my role as a father. If I'm not able to attend one of my children's events or help them with their homework, I feel like I'm a complete failure as a parent, even though I know deep down that's not true.

Therapist: That's another great example of all-or-nothing thinking. It's common for people to have these types of thoughts, especially when it comes to roles or responsibilities that are important to them, like being a parent or excelling at work.

The good news is that CBT provides us with tools to challenge and change these cognitive distortions. One technique we can use is to examine the evidence for and against these thoughts. For example, when you think, "I'm a complete failure as a parent," we can look at the evidence that supports or refutes this thought. What might be some evidence against this thought?

Patient: Well, I suppose the fact that I provide for my children, spend time with them when I can, and always make sure they know I love them is evidence that I'm not a complete failure as a parent.

Therapist: Absolutely! Those are all great examples of evidence against the thought that you're a complete failure as a parent. By examining the evidence, we can start to challenge and change these cognitive distortions and develop more balanced, realistic thoughts.

Another technique we can use is to consider alternative perspectives. When you have a negative thought, like "I'll never be able to meet expectations at work," try to consider alternative viewpoints. What might be a more balanced or realistic perspective?

Patient: A more balanced perspective might be that everyone makes mistakes, and one instance of not meeting expectations doesn't mean I'll never be able to do so. I can learn from this experience and use it to improve my work in the future.

Therapist: That's a great alternative perspective, Alejandro. By considering alternative viewpoints, we can start to challenge the validity of our negative thoughts and develop more balanced, realistic thinking patterns.

As we continue with our sessions, we'll work on identifying and challenging cognitive distortions and developing more adaptive thoughts and behaviors. How do you feel about what we've discussed so far?
